9511F9AB91AE425CAB13EA44EA8C4E4C.description: Comment on how and why communication varies in different contexts.

9F52B24F51764992B51E7D47FE2DFF13.description: Evaluate own and others' talk, including what went well and what could be improved next time.

F74C7851E8344B54A5CCCBB2A6CA840F.description: Begin to make choices about the most appropriate media for a particular presentation.

BDDE5501B9894635AD51F4CD58EC41C5.description: Plan and deliver independent and group presentations confidently to a range of audiences, adapting presentations appropriately to the audience.

AB495D974C044350ADE7AA2A117AC7E5.description: Convey ideas about characters in drama through deliberate choice of speech, gesture and movement.

92FB39DC1D9D49CA825599FCC039680F.description: Read aloud with accuracy, and increasing confidence and style.

E65563ECA1DB4EBABAA5F14C60C029AD.description: Take turns in a discussion, building on what others have said.

68A43DB036664D8CA63CCBEF6EB62983.description: Extend a discussion by asking and answering questions to refine ideas.

9AB7046FD0444CAAAA57EBD137CF4A74.description: Show consideration of another point of view.

742C4358E9E0401E9DFBD3FAFCA55A4A.description: Take different assigned roles within groups, and begin to assign roles within a group.

FF8D946FCA354ED5A6848EA4312945EA.description: Listen, reflect on what is heard and give a reasoned response.

1ECA1A001FF9477ABC6136EDFB24FF25.description: Show awareness of different audiences, e.g. by using the appropriate register.

64D6F0C7DF564499895EFE961FFEF8B6.description: Adapt non-verbal communication techniques for different purposes and contexts.

A305B8027FB5455BA5AA75AF40295BC7.description: Use language to convey ideas and opinions, with some detail.

85C1DC0A30CD48F280F44E57FBD70BF0.description: Structure relevant information in a way that supports the purpose and aids the listener's understanding.

E19C950608224AC189131A4FFB406365.description: Speak precisely either with concision or at length, as appropriate to context.

ABA708FCA5EC40A2951D6D7E7E94E7BE.description: Proofread for grammar, spelling and punctuation errors, and make corrections, including using on-screen tools.

9B39C0B88F5D49A1981BA49DFE73D0CB.description: Evaluate own and others’ writing, suggesting improvements for sense, accuracy and content, including to enhance the effect.

67E7BB80600C493B8C8F7E941DB7FCE6.description: Begin to choose appropriate ways to lay out and present texts to suit the purpose and audience (handwritten, printed and onscreen).

A84D1FE29264409A84421284C923A924.description: Explore and use different ways of making notes (e.g. bulleted lists, mind maps) and use them to inform writing.

7E7C8E07794D48A6BCA206CF166D98CC.description: Write legibly and fluently for different purposes, including choosing the writing implement that is best suited for a task.

204C539EF7E04339A2FF58ED8B478032.description: When writing non-fiction texts, present and justify a consistent viewpoint.

54C09649C6034F479EDCBE1EE6C795B5.description: Develop writing of a range of text types for a specified audience, using appropriate content and language.

B424DD2354DB494BBF3969B0CAFD4453.description: Develop writing for a purpose using language and features appropriate for a range of text types.

D4E8BD292CA0482E9473BB5D4548DD68.description: Write a playscript, including production notes and stage directions to guide performance.

8D7E636FD1CE45E1B2DF3C6AB6727D74.description: Express a viewpoint in fiction through a character's opinions about a setting or other characters.

4717EA39B6DC47F08CCD97C481B1C396.description: Write new scenes or characters into a story; rewrite events from the viewpoint of another character.

770E578966B94917824DF5352069BA93.description: Use effective planning to inform the content and structure of writing, e.g. paragraphs or sections.

4BBCE4210D47491A98E2F0A40A282A88.description: Develop creative writing in a range of different genres of fiction and types of poems.

9D403FAE320F4D82B69614EABD563DE1.description: Use organisational features appropriate to the text type, e.g. bulleted and numbered lists.

20429E2B58CA487687B2564F5779840E.description: Organise ideas in paragraphs and sections to achieve an appropriate effect.

182DC5B7A7CA419BACC05F8D4A281B32.description: Begin to develop ideas cohesively across longer pieces of writing.

924C53879516492B80513ACB57846112.description: Use a wide range of adverbs and adverbial phrases.

3A542376FB89488496C0F0C1A503BE48.description: Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs correctly, e.g. better, best; smaller, smallest; more quickly, most quickly.

FE73B19CD34A4357A1AACD4B47DA5337.description: Use pronouns, including possessive pronouns (e.g. theirs, mine), appropriately so it is clear to what or whom they refer.

503C4A974C82402690328482638180DA.description: Use a wide range of modal verbs accurately to express degrees of possibility, e.g. should, would, could.

5319760613D94259AF9E2AAADDBEA39B.description: Understand how to create multi-clause sentences by combining simple sentences and reordering clauses; use simple, compound and complex sentences.

EC198EC214EA4B2687C3C7D76EEF0569.description: Begin to use commas to separate clauses within sentences and clarify meaning in complex sentences.

92001776E92A476BB23793A83C0DC2F1.description: Use own lists of interesting and significant words, dictionaries and thesauruses to extend the range of vocabulary used in written work.

A04D3F21E5AC4A0D90E801248B898EF2.description: Begin to use figurative language to evoke an imaginative response from the reader.

CECB7630BCF240B494675B9EB0FEB7CC.description: Choose and use words and phrases carefully to convey feeling and mood.

42A9D696159549EA879FCB0E533FBC3D.description: Explore synonyms and words conveying shades of meaning, and use them accurately in own writing.

9C471BE8AE564DFE9D13F4B24354E86A.description: Use specialised vocabulary accurately to match a familiar topic.

264447BE45A744218473B815D525737F.description: Use paper-based and on-screen tools to find the correct spelling of words; keep and use spelling logs of misspelt words, and identify words that need to be learned.

A773B26EEE184E6FB2583E94FB0BF5A6.description: Use effective strategies, including spelling rules and exceptions, and using known spellings to work out the spelling of related words, to spell a range of words correctly.

0506F2B699AC4263B9936B473E93927B.description: Explore exceptions to known spelling rules.

E2D0AFC42BA34CB0B00FE9DF3A317614.description: Spell words with less common letter strings which may be pronounced differently, e.g. pour, hour; piece, pie.

E12553BB4CBF4B66B10B4D2033161239.description: Explore and use accurately words that have the same spelling but different meanings (homonyms), e.g. wave (hand gesture, hair curl, sea movement, etc.).

7355379A195443B9BD87ACBBF7116BFB.description: Explore and use spelling rules for suffixes that begin with vowels and suffixes that begin with consonants.

DCC22BF9D1CE4ADFBD87E9CD3431E022.description: Spell words with a wide range of common prefixes and suffixes, including understanding ways of creating opposites, e.g. un-, im-.

E557A96149DB40178C72E41381C400FF.description: Explore and use rules for single and double consonants, e.g. full, -ful, -fully.

E23B669CC1F64AA293C2CD425E6F1725.description: Explore and use ‘silent’ vowels and syllables in polysyllabic words, e.g. library, interest.

92A0A83FAA31407199BA7F14122CDC68.description: Explore and use spellings of unstressed vowel phonemes at the end of words, e.g. /з:/ (‘er’) at the end of butter, /i:/ ('ee’) at the end of city.

F7CF2B30DFE04729BC6439FA80761972.description: Begin to consider how readers might react differently to the same text, depending on where or when they are reading it.

220E77BAA9844304AE9CEEA5151B4938.description: Develop preferences about favourite writers and share recommendations with others.

E63EB0EAC7634BC998406D04A8A989A3.description: Express personal responses to texts, including predictions, opinions and reflections.

3F84338D8F574923B6BECA21C2708DA9.description: Enjoy independent and shared reading of fiction genres, poems, playscripts and non-fiction texts.

6D0B622B116E4BD88718168C14932EFF.description: Comment on how a viewpoint is expressed in fiction and non-fiction texts.

59B8D1E9B743402CB804BC89B44A9B93.description: Recognise, compare and contrast the themes, features and language of texts.

0904CA678337470C80AFAA92504125B4.description: Support answers to questions with reference to, or quotations from, one or more points in a text.

F79D874AFFE84A99B2E3F3BD15A25CE0.description: Locate and use relevant information from a single text or different texts.

13BCD9B320714C7F9D68160C3E1E4E96.description: Use scanning and skimming appropriately depending on the type of information required.

5342F2A38C444CFFB34DAC5083AB2679.description: Distinguish between fact and opinion in a range of texts.

458286EDB8ED44FCA6C6FCC5EC7C3CBB.description: Make inferences from texts, including about the relationships between story characters.

97BE09399A604B2B9C44247F61E5545B.description: Use a range of types of clues in stories (e.g. personality of characters) to predict what might happen next.

658550E5BB3948748F25B6D26E60D081.description: Explore implicit meanings in a range of texts.

E2F481A094DD4EAFB85AC73C1FE05038.description: Recognise and compare the dramatic conventions of playscripts and films, including how they contribute to the development of characters and settings.

495C3781E13C4188A9B23A3EFE6745E3.description: Extract main points from a text, and group and link ideas.

2E139E3A683A4AE09FAD59CB6246C277.description: Explore explicit meanings in a range of texts.

AA3DEA7E54364282809DBA8221B1B1D2.description: Identify, discuss and compare the purposes and features of different non-fiction text types, including evaluating texts for purpose and clarity, and recognising use of personal and impersonal style.

E3621BDCA6624981819BC96C03C12425.description: Read and explore a range of non-fiction text types.

F222DB7714A547288910D023EB46C740.description: Identify, discuss and compare different fiction genres and their typical characteristics.

09A43B76E7C941448950333AD21474A8.description: Read and explore a range of fiction genres, poems and playscripts, including identifying the contribution of any visual elements or multimedia.

5D5CE9FCEC3A4FE6AD862E5BE32B0A96.description: Understand the difference between fiction and non-fiction texts and locate books by classification.

34BE79416F80405691BFEBF83378B3DB.description: Explore and recognise how different effects can be achieved by sequencing sections and paragraphs in different ways.

571CDA0E02354D01B6DF6F11C6CD846D.description: Explore and recognise the key features of text structure in a range of different fiction and non-fiction texts, including poems and playscripts.

C1C5F05F7A634FB785D842BB3CE8C293.description: Explore and describe the progression of ideas in a text; compare the progression in different texts.

D98FB83C1BB44ABAB17CD9CEA15E26B0.description: Explore in texts the conventions of standard English.

5A7E5C1F5B334838ACCFC13A30F84980.description: Explore how different modal verbs express degrees of possibility, e.g. should, would, could.

E5DE0257547A4A8F85618BCC0FA06070.description: Explore in texts use of pronouns, including possessive pronouns (e.g. theirs, mine), to avoid repetition of nouns while still maintaining clarity.

F5BAEFFC2B2C45EEACA2F003A484E532.description: Explore and discuss different types of nouns, including abstract nouns, and how quantifiers (e.g. fewer, less) relate to countable and uncountable nouns.

E39ACDA97B214BC9A4099E84E03A0CB5.description: Recognise different clauses within sentences and the connectives that link them.

81B51CEEFA0940EDB1B7E9D478A20127.description: Explore in texts, and understand, grammar and punctuation differences between direct and reported speech.

23ABA6CADC764DCBBDC61FCC36245E37.description: Begin to explain how figurative language creates imagery in texts and takes understanding beyond the literal.

AB1F67B49C97434F813575B6FE5BCA5D.description: Identify figurative language in texts, including metaphors and personification.

9B2651FAE6F349FDBFE19475FCF08046.description: Comment on a writer's choice of language, including how it conveys feeling and mood.

6470AE0B5DB8441A8BE5ACB9CD929099.description: Locate words efficiently in alphabetically organised lists.

6F0263871B0448FCB237124E290A0906.description: Identify and record interesting and significant words, and synonyms, from texts to inform own writing.

E9E33E71EC374146AD0DF3E26290FDD6.description: Explore common idiomatic phrases and their meanings.

10F520E7D4DC4526B8FAEFBB586B51F6.description: Deduce the meanings of unfamiliar words, including using context and knowledge of root words, prefixes and suffixes.

AFC30209E718499EBD8CA96928E5157A.description: By end of Stage 4 learners should have a secure understanding of phonics.
